title: How to Prevent Buffet Bottlenecks

steps.headline: Make sure that guests can walk around the table.
steps.description: It is not a good idea to set up the table so that one side is blocked or pushed up against a wall or window. The more that guests can flow around the whole table, the better.

steps.headline: Put knives, forks, plates, serviettes etc.
steps.description: at both ends of the table. This will encourage guests to start from either end rather than all congregating at one end. It will also encourage people to continue their conversations in pairs as they obtain their meal choices.

steps.headline: Put condiments at both ends.
steps.description: Again, this alleviates the need for everyone standing at the same spot waiting for sauce, pickles or salt and pepper.

steps.headline: Divide some dishes if possible.
steps.description: Some foods, like salads and baskets of bread rolls, can be easily divided so that you put equal portions at either end of the table. This will also alleviate the need for slowing down the flow at one end.

steps.headline: Keep main dishes in the middle.
steps.description: As guests work their way from either side, they will meet in the central part of the table to obtain the substantial part of the meal. Provide two sets of tongs, large spoons etc., placed on resting plates either side of the main course dishes. At this point, guests can use their own etiquette to wait patiently for one another.

The more that guests can flow around the whole table, the better. Put knives, forks, plates, serviettes etc. at both ends of the table. This will encourage guests to start from either end rather than all congregating at one end. It will also encourage people to continue their conversations in pairs as they obtain their meal choices. Put condiments at both ends. Again, this alleviates the need for everyone standing at the same spot waiting for sauce, pickles or salt and pepper. Divide some dishes if possible. Some foods, like salads and baskets of bread rolls, can be easily divided so that you put equal portions at either end of the table. This will also alleviate the need for slowing down the flow at one end. Keep main dishes in the middle. As guests work their way from either side, they will meet in the central part of the table to obtain the substantial part of the meal. Provide two sets of tongs, large spoons etc., placed on resting plates either side of the main course dishes. At this point, guests can use their own etiquette to wait patiently for one another.
